positive.review:
[if u from wc3 u will love it]
In 2009, during my last semester of high school, I created the original Legion TD map on Warcraft 3. I made it just for fun, to play with friends from school.

As much as I loved Dota, Footies, Wintermaul, and every other TD out there, nothing ever felt like the game for me. I wanted gameplay that was:
a) team vs. team, so I could queue with my bros.
b) high skill cap, since I'm a tryhard.
c) strategic, without all the micro, since I have terrible aim.
and I couldn't find anything else that checked all those boxes.

...7 years of work and 283,246 lines of code later...

I am deeply tired, but proud of the game Legion TD 2 has become. Chill, like a TD, yet deeply strategic. After thousands of hours, there's more to discover.

I can honestly say that after a long day of working on Legion TD 2, I still like to relax and unwind by playing...Legion TD 2.

üí¨The game is still very much alive and is not going to die anytime soon. The number of online players is small but constant, approximately the same as 1 year ago. New players and long-time players share the game, and it usually takes a couple of minutes to find a match. The game receives updates very frequently. Fixes for bugs are provided, but also the creation of new bugs is part of the process. The balance is adjusted so that players do not get stuck using the same strategies, and there are occasions when new cosmetics are introduced.

üéÆAlthough there are no in-game advantages provided by the game, it still allows for donations towards cosmetics (skins, backgrounds, etc.) and nickname changes. The good news is that if you belong to a guild, you will be able to get these perks for free. With the guild's progress, all members receive premium currency in their accounts for free. Many aspects of the game are very much connected to guilds.

It is a team sport, and that is it. Do you want to be victorious more often? Then, play as a team. A well-organized group of medium-skilled players can easily defeat the top-level players if, the latter, do not coordinate their actions and rather play as they want. Does this imply that, for those who do not want to join a guild and have no friends, there is no activity available in the game? No, it doesn't. The game provides a great and simple to use ping system. Just with a quick movement of your mouse, you can show what you want to do to your team mates. Would you like to attack on the next wave? Alert them that you are afraid of an attack and require support? Let them know that you have no idea what to do next? All this can be done without the need of chat, and your team mates will receive the information in the language of their client.

Matchmaking in ranked mode (2 on 2) it is good; in classic mode (4 against 4) it is often random. A player-matching system is in place for classic mode. You will get bonuses throughout the match if your team is made up of weaker players than your opponent. But honestly, it doesn't make much of a difference. When your teammate is oblivious to the abilities of a certain unit, no amount of bonuses will help him/ her. Winning over them is also not so much enjoyable. If beginners were kept to play only with beginners, it would be a better situation. But evidently, there is not enough online playing, and at times, they are sometimes used to dilute groups of more experienced players.

üëçPositive.
- Game support
- Constant balance changes
- Various modes
- Huge build variety
- Good optimization.

üëéNegative.
- Takes Time to Get Rewarding
- Steep Learning Curve
- Matchmaking Issues
- Graphics are not for everyone.

üßæSummary.
The production quality is undoubtedly the work of professionals, and, most significantly, true enthusiasts of Warcraft and the primal Legion TD are behind it. The user interface always displays everything necessary for the game.

The game is a paradox: it is extremely easy to play but at the same time very difficult. After playing the tutorial (which is strongly suggested), you can straightway enter the game and even find yourself relatively at ease. And only a few players would be able to memorize the precise stats of each unit from the local encyclopedia, learn about the changes through reading patch notes, and spend hundreds of hours in the sandbox just to acquire mastery of their own that would be very hard to pass on to others. What has been effective in this update may stop being so in the next one, and you'll have to come up with new builds and formations. This can be done consciously, through trial and error, or by watching other players.
üéØ8/10
üí¨Legion is suitable for both professional play and casual play, but if you are a fan of the game, it will require a long-term commitment.

üß†The game is really a time-consuming deal quite literally. It is perfectly balanced, having characters that are neither intrinsically good nor bad, unlike in the case of Warcraft 3. (There is a bear that can single-handedly kill all the enemies in a wave, or a mass build that can just spoil the game, auras covering the entire battlefield, and if you're not lucky to get one, your gaming experience will definitely be bad. And so on.)

An enjoyable and captivating tower defense game, the best I‚Äôve ever played in this genre. Excellent graphics, novel mechanics, ranking, and a variety of modes. 
It‚Äôs a great thrill to play with friends, devise new tactics and combinations, engage in different modes, and mess up each other because someone made a mistake: couldn't guard a wave, deployed troops on an unspecified wave, one hit the enemy while the other didn't, and so on. A game on a 4/4 map usually lasts 40-60 minutes on average, no more. But it can be quicker on a 2/2 map.

Most importantly, the art style is amazing and at the same time, the statistics of each battle are shown on the screen! Damage done, taken, and so forth, and even the old Warcraft 3 scoreboard is shown: incoming and outgoing damage by armor type and unit attack.

For me, the only drawback is that the community is quite small. It seems that some games are quickly matched but in one of the games, I thought of checking the players' statistics. One player had a 20% win rate and the graph looked like an ECG. Their ratings were always above a certain point. So I would say those were bots; the graphs of real players look quite different. Still human players are often caught. Bots are compensating for the long waiting time until someone completes the game. Out of 450 people, the waiting time is around 5 minutes for a match. Always the same players. It would be awesome to meet new ones but sadly, for some reason, very few people seem to be interested in this exceptional tower defense game!

‚úÖThe Good.
- Variety of Units and Towers
- Beautiful Visuals and Polished Design
- Strategic Depth
- Unique Multiplayer Gameplay

‚ùåThe Bad.
- Limited Solo Play
- Pay-to-Win Concerns
- Dependency on Teamwork
- Matches Can Be Long

üßæIn Conclusion.
In order to grasp the game completely, I advise playing with bots for a while. The developers are constantly very passionate (in my opinion) about their creation, always releasing new patches, coming up with new game modes, and introducing new defenders for the King.
This game is worth my suggestion. It is a fantastic multiplayer game where you can win without even having to talk to your teammates. It can be a good time-wasting activity, and for some people, it might even be a great way to socialize.
I suggest trying it out; it can definitely turn out to be thrilling.
7.5/10üîö

In general, the game is similar to legion td maps from warcraft 3. There are some interesting mechanics and different types of mini-games. Playing ranked or 1v1 is more difficult than classic 4v4. I would say that changes in monthly patches affect the game styles, and sometimes you have to adjust your strategies to match the patches. But when you've figured out the basic strategies after a few months, you'll continue to play them, sometimes finding new ideas for the gameplay, especially in 4v4 with different types of mini-games that change every few hours. After two years of playing, I've managed to reach the top 100 in the classic legend rank, and I'm close to achieving this in ranked 2v2. The game is interesting, but there's not much variety after a few months or years of playing due to the nature of the game itself. So for me, it's more of a game I play occasionally to relax and check out new masterminds, gameplays, and strategies, rather than something competitive that I spend hours grinding. I would recommend playing this game if you enjoy autochess and Warcraft 3 mini-games tho.

I appreciate the developers giving us a chance to try this game in its entirety. Here's what I can tell you from my short time with the game.
1. It seems to have a focus on PVP
2. It has a decent tutorial that gets you up and running quickly
3. It feels pretty easy to learn and get into
4. The problems you'll have to solve while playing have mostly to do with determining what to build and when, whether you want to add another tower and which ones, or add to your economy. This balance between power and economy becomes the central problem you'll have to solve. There are tool tips that tell you how much power you should try to have at certain times in the game relieving some of the burden on the player. 

For me as someone who prefers to play TD as a single player game, I found myself feeling like I didn't have enough choices to make the game interesting. I also wish there could have been a micromanagement mechanic like buying and selling towers at the right times to maximize revenue through interest or maybe even a guy I could control to fight enemies with. I noticed that at certain levels you do get spells, but i don't know how interesting that made the game since I didn't really make it that far before giving up on the game. 

TLDR: I appreciate the chance to try,  but it's not for me.
Game is fun but requires to be online for singleplayer and against bots.

Fix your broken matchmaking and even more broken timeout distribution system and what's the problem with leaving a lost game without wasting extra 15-20 minutes pointlessly playing? Yes, there's a surrender option in the menu, but if your teammate is a loser, which is true 99% of the time because they don't want to surrender, then what other solution, dear developers? Why should I have to sit through every game like a bot? I think you're just stupid if you can't admit the obvious. Oh yeah, they also created a ban system for leaving games.
So, if the random player gives you useless units, stay in the game until the end. If you have another loser on your team, stay in until the end anyway.
Basically, make a proper 1v1 mode or cancel your nonsense with a timeout for leaving matches. The game could be much better optimized. The menu already takes up 3.0 gigabytes of RAM. You know, in a Tower Defense game - one of the simplest there is. To make matters worse, the developers decided to make the default detail levels 'Ultra' and 'High.' Did I mention this game is not well optimized.

The tutorial does not work in some places and makes no sense in others. Case to point, what does "you must send +6 Snail before the combat ends." The reason it fails you is that sending mercenaries earns you PERMANENT income even if they all die. That makes zero sense.

Was this game beta tested at all? How do you fail at making a tutorial? You are supposed to understand the game as a developer. Even if you know that this Snail is a weak mercenary i.e. an offensive troop, it is pointless because Snails are so weak they are practically useless at dealing damage.

Long loading times for a game of a couple gigabytes in size.

Obvious AI voices. It is disturbingly cheap stuff. They picked one with a robotic BBC accent. It feels to calculated because it conforms the weird stereotype of Americans liking that accent for more or less perverse reasons.

If you try to use DX 9 renders, the 'Continue' buttons stop working. Great held-together-by-a-tape programming right there.

Even after you realize you know what you are supposed to do, the boredom gets even worse because it is a vapid horde mode of diminishing some enemy units HP to zero. It is trite even by Tower Defense standards.

This game is extremely overt about it being about spamming units in the most automated and routine way possible. That does not inspire having fun. Instead it is about inserting the players into the arbitrary rails set by the developers. The whole concept is flawed. It makes Defence of the Ancients (DOTA) seem like the best thing ever in comparison (it is the same repetitive slop though at least you have the freedom of movement in DOTA).

I appreciate the developers giving us a chance to try this game in its entirety. Here's what I can tell you from my short time with the game.
1. It seems to have a focus on PVP
2. It has a decent tutorial that gets you up and running quickly
3. It feels pretty easy to learn and get into
4. The problems you'll have to solve while playing have mostly to do with determining what to build and when, whether you want to add another tower and which ones, or add to your economy. This balance between power and economy becomes the central problem you'll have to solve. There are tool tips that tell you how much power you should try to have at certain times in the game relieving some of the burden on the player. 

For me as someone who prefers to play TD as a single player game, I found myself feeling like I didn't have enough choices to make the game interesting. I also wish there could have been a micromanagement mechanic like buying and selling towers at the right times to maximize revenue through interest or maybe even a guy I could control to fight enemies with. I noticed that at certain levels you do get spells, but i don't know how interesting that made the game since I didn't really make it that far before giving up on the game. 

TLDR: I appreciate the chance to try,  but it's not for me.

I played this game for many, many hours. First coming from WC like many others, this game felt like a dream come true. The ways to play were numerous, enjoyable and allowed a lot of experimentation. Over the years this has... changed. Mostly, this is due to repeated nerfs that have reduced the usefulness of troops to a near zero. 

As an example, the eco playstyle. If one player in the team chose to focus on sending, while the other builds, it created a new dynamic. However, this game over time has implemented many hidden systems. This results in significantly reduced income, materials and other nerfs that are not visible, mentioned or evident. It translates to not being able to pinpoint why your strategy that was very successful in the past is now completely unviable. 

If you do not continually review the patch notes, experiment and develop your playstyle, you will lose. If you try to play the game casually, a few rounds a week, you will lose. If you have a preferred playstyle, eventually you will lose. 

The game is great, however the continual forced nerfs in order to push players to play certain ways are very much killing the game. It feels as though the dev watches the matches like TV and just tries to control what shows are on.

As an example, double lock in was a mastermind shortly... Emphasis on shortly.

If you want a fresh new experience daily, this game is perfect. You'll never know what to expect. If you want a familiar favourite, this may not be the one anymore; sadly.
